text: What has hands but cannot clap? — A clock!
analysis: Simple polysemy: 'hands' means both human body parts and clock pointers. This teaches learners that words can have multiple meanings depending on context.

text: What gets wetter as it dries? — A towel!
analysis: Paradox created through dual meaning of 'dries': the towel dries things (makes them dry) while becoming wet itself.

text: Why did the pencil go to bed? Because it was feeling dull.
analysis: Literal vs. figurative meaning: 'dull' means both 'not sharp' (literal, for pencils) and 'boring/tired' (figurative, for people).

text: Why did the math book look sad? Because it had too many problems.
analysis: Polysemy of 'problems': mathematical exercises vs. difficulties/troubles. Personification adds to humor.

text: I used to be a banker, but I lost interest.
analysis: Idiomatic double meaning: 'lost interest' means both 'became bored' and 'lost bank interest' (financial term).

text: I got fired from the calendar factory. I took a day off.
analysis: Pragmatic implicature and irony. The connection between 'calendar factory' (makes calendars showing days) and 'took a day off' creates ironic incongruity.

text: Parallel lines have so much in common — it's a shame they'll never meet.
analysis: Anthropomorphism and category violation. Human emotional concepts (having things in common, meeting socially) are applied to mathematical entities.

text: Waiter: 'How did you find your steak, sir?' Customer: 'I just looked next to the potatoes and there it was.'
analysis: Pragmatic failure through literal interpretation. The waiter's 'find' is an idiom meaning 'What did you think of it?' but the customer interprets it literally as 'locate physically'.

text: A: 'Excuse me, does this bus go to Tashkent?' B: 'No, it goes by itself.'
analysis: Misunderstanding of intended speech act. Speaker A performs an indirect request for information about the bus route, but Speaker B responds to the literal (absurd) meaning about the bus's autonomy.

text: Teacher: 'If I give you 2 cats and another 2 cats and another 2, how many do you have?' Student: 'Seven.' Teacher: 'How?' Student: 'Because I already have one cat!'
analysis: Pragmatic frame misalignment. The teacher establishes a hypothetical mathematical frame, but the student responds with real-world context, violating the Maxim of Relation by being irrelevantly accurate.

text: Friend 1: 'You're early again!' Friend 2: 'Yes, only thirty minutes late this time.'
analysis: Sarcasm as face-saving strategy. Friend 1 uses irony to criticize politely (saying 'early' when meaning 'late'). Friend 2 uses self-deprecating humor to acknowledge the criticism and maintain social harmony.

text: A: 'How was the movie?' B: 'Well, the seats were comfortable.'
analysis: Violates Maxim of Quantity and Relation. By not directly answering and focusing on irrelevant detail, B implicates the movie was bad (if it were good, they'd say so).

text: Patient: 'Doctor, I think I'm a dog.' Doctor: 'How long have you felt this way?' Patient: 'Ever since I was a puppy.'
analysis: Violates Grice's Maxim of Quality (truthfulness). The patient treats a false premise as true, creating humor through pragmatic violation. The doctor's question also treats the delusion seriously, compounding the absurdity.

text: My wife told me to take the spider out instead of killing it. We went for a few drinks. Nice guy — wants to be a web developer.
analysis: Deliberate misinterpretation of idiom: 'take out' means 'remove from the house' vs. 'go on a date'. Extended through 'web developer' pun (spider webs + tech job).

text: I hate people who use big words to make themselves sound perspicacious.
analysis: Performative contradiction. The speaker criticizes the very behavior they perform - using a big word ('perspicacious' = intelligent) to sound intelligent. Meta-humor about language use itself.

text: An Englishman, even if he is alone, forms an orderly queue of one. — George Mikes
analysis: Cultural stereotype humor about British obsession with queuing/orderliness. Requires cultural knowledge to understand the exaggeration for comic effect.

text: In Uzbekistan, when grandmother says 'You look thin,' she means 'I'm about to force-feed you for three hours.' When she says 'You look healthy,' you're actually thin and she's worried.
analysis: Cultural script about Uzbek hospitality and indirect communication. 'Thin' is culturally negative (implies not being well-fed/cared for), so it's expressed indirectly through opposite comment.

text: An American says 'I'll think about it' = Maybe. An Uzbek says 'I'll think about it' = Polite no. A German says 'I'll think about it' = I actually will think about it and give you a detailed answer later.
analysis: Cross-cultural pragmatic differences in the same phrase. Different cultures use identical words with completely different illocutionary force.

text: I'm reading a book about anti-gravity. It's impossible to put down!
analysis: Dual meaning: 'put down' as 'stop reading' (idiomatic) vs. 'place downward' (literal). The anti-gravity theme reinforces both meanings.

text: I used to play piano by ear, but now I use my hands.
analysis: Idiom literalization: 'play by ear' means 'play without sheet music' (idiomatically), treated as literal body part usage.

text: Time flies like an arrow. Fruit flies like a banana.
analysis: Syntactic ambiguity: First sentence = time passes quickly (flies=verb). Second sentence reinterprets: fruit flies (noun) + like (verb) + banana (object). Requires reanalysis of grammatical structure.

text: Email from student: 'Hey Prof, I need an extension lol send it to me when u can thx' — Professor's internal reaction: *blocks student*
analysis: Multiple pragmatic failures: too informal register ('Hey', 'lol', 'u', 'thx'), inappropriate directness ('I need'), wrong speech act (demanding not requesting), no justification, no acknowledgment of imposition. Power asymmetry completely ignored.

text: Foreigner at Uzbek wedding reception refuses food: 'No thanks, I'm full.' Host's face shows deep offense. Guide whispers: 'Just take it. You're rejecting their hospitality!'
analysis: Sociopragmatic failure: Direct refusal is pragmatically inappropriate in Uzbek hospitality culture. Must use indirect strategies: accept small portion, praise the food, give elaborate reason. Direct 'no' threatens host's positive face.

text: I went to buy camouflage pants but couldn't find any.
analysis: Absurdist humor from literal interpretation of camouflage function (military concealment) applied to shopping context.

text: I told my wife she was drawing her eyebrows too high. She looked surprised.
analysis: Visual pun: 'surprised' facial expression involves raised eyebrows, so overly-high drawn eyebrows create permanent surprised look.

text: Early to bed and early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy, and wise. But nobody wants to hang out with him because he's always asleep.
analysis: Proverb subversion: Takes traditional wisdom literally to expose its social pragmatic failure - following the advice creates social isolation.

text: Oh great, another meeting that could have been an email.
analysis: Sarcasm violating Maxim of Quality: 'great' means opposite (terrible). Expresses frustration with workplace inefficiency through ironic enthusiasm.

text: Friend posts obvious fact on social media. Comment: 'Wow, what groundbreaking insight.'
analysis: Sarcastic compliment meaning opposite: not groundbreaking at all. Online sarcasm is harder to detect without tone, making pragmatic competence crucial.

text: Uzbek mother: 'Have you eaten?' Translation: 'I love you, I care about you, you're probably starving, let me feed you immediately regardless of your answer.'
analysis: Culturally-specific formulaic expression. 'Have you eaten?' is not information-seeking (violates Maxim of Quantity) but relationship-maintaining. Expected answer: always accept food offer to show appreciation.

text: When Uzbek says 'Come visit us!' to someone they just met, Foreigner thinks: 'Wow, new friend!' Reality: It's formulaic politeness, like 'Have a nice day' - not literal invitation.
analysis: Pragmatic transfer problem: Literal interpretation of culturally conventional politeness formula. In Uzbek culture, this is positive face work, not binding invitation.

text: A: 'Do you know what time it is?' B: 'Yes.' [walks away]
analysis: Violates cooperative principle by being hyper-literal. The question is an indirect request (tell me the time), not yes/no question (do you possess this knowledge). B's response is pragmatically inappropriate despite being truthful.

text: A: 'Can you pass the salt?' B: 'Yes, I can.' [doesn't pass it]
analysis: Similar violation: 'Can you' is conventionally an indirect request, not ability question. B treats it as literal question about capability.

text: Two antennas met on a roof, fell in love and got married. The ceremony wasn't much, but the reception was excellent.
analysis: Technical pun: 'reception' means both 'wedding party' and 'signal reception' (antennas receive signals). Requires knowledge of both social and technical domains.

text: I'm reading a book on the history of glue. I just can't seem to put it down.
analysis: Multiple meanings: 'put down' = stop reading OR place downward. Glue theme adds literal adhesive meaning. Meta-joke about addictive reading.

text: Descartes walks into a bar. Bartender asks 'Would you like a drink?' Descartes replies 'I think not' — and disappears.
analysis: Philosophical humor requiring knowledge of Descartes' 'I think, therefore I am.' If he thinks not, he doesn't exist. Very high pragmatic load requiring external knowledge.

text: Why did the student eat his homework? Because the teacher said it was a piece of cake!
analysis: Idiom literalization: 'piece of cake' means 'very easy' (idiomatically), treated literally as actual cake. Common in children's humor but teaches pragmatic principles.

text: Let's eat, Grandma! vs. Let's eat Grandma! — Punctuation saves lives.
analysis: Demonstrates how pragmatic meaning depends on more than words - punctuation changes grammatical structure and thus meaning entirely (invitation to eat together vs. cannibalism).

text: Tourist in London: 'Where's the bathroom?' British person, slightly offended: 'You mean the toilet?' Tourist: 'No, I want to take a bath.' British: '...We call it the loo.'
analysis: Register and vocabulary pragmatic failure: 'Bathroom' in American English = toilet, in British English = room with bath. Tourist's literal interpretation creates confusion. Shows regional pragmatic variation.

text: Never trust atoms. They make up everything.
analysis: Scientific pun: 'make up' means both 'constitute/compose' (atoms make up matter) and 'lie/fabricate' (slang). Meta-humor about language itself.

text: I'm great at multitasking. I can waste time, be unproductive, and procrastinate all at once.
analysis: Self-deprecating humor with semantic play: lists three ways of saying the same thing (not real multitasking). Subverts boasting expectation.

text: Nasriddin Afandi was asked: 'Which is more useful, the sun or the moon?' He replied: 'The moon, of course! It shines when it's dark. The sun only shines when it's already light!'
analysis: Classic 'wise fool' humour from Central Asian tradition. The absurd logic (moon more useful because it shines in darkness) actually inverts normal thinking. Similar mechanism to British absurdist humour but with warmer, more direct delivery.

text: Uzbek grandmother: 'Have you eaten?' (Translation: 'I love you and am about to feed you for three hours regardless of your answer.')
analysis: This formulaic question is NOT an information request - it's a hospitality ritual and expression of care. The humour comes from recognizing the gap between literal meaning and pragmatic function.

text: At an Uzbek wedding, guest says 'I'm full.' Host hears: 'Please convince me more enthusiastically to eat.'
analysis: Cultural script mismatch played for humour. In Uzbek hospitality, initial refusals are part of a ritual - the host is expected to insist. 'I'm full' is round one of negotiation, not a final answer.

text: British weather report: 'Not exactly tropical today, is it?' (Said during a blizzard)
analysis: Classic British understatement. The enormous gap between 'not exactly tropical' and 'severe blizzard' creates humour. Requires recognizing that mild language = strong meaning.

text: British person: 'I'm not saying my cooking is bad, but the smoke alarm cheers when I order takeaway.'
analysis: Self-deprecating humour - the speaker mocks their own inability. This is a bonding mechanism, not genuine self-criticism. Expected response: sympathetic laughter, not cooking lessons.

text: British boss to employee who made a mistake: 'Well, that's certainly ONE way to approach it.'
analysis: Indirect criticism through understatement. 'One way' implies there are BETTER ways. The politeness is surface-level; the criticism is real but softened. An Uzbek boss might be more direct.

text: [Heavy rain outside] British person: 'Lovely day for a picnic, isn't it?' (Said with completely straight face)
analysis: Deadpan sarcasm - no smile, no tone change, just words that obviously contradict reality. The humour requires the listener to recognize the content mismatch without any delivery signals.

text: Uzbek student in UK: 'The host family never offered me more food! So unwelcoming!' British host family: 'We said help yourself. They never took any more. They must not have liked it.'
analysis: Classic cross-cultural pragmatic failure. Uzbek expectation: multiple insistent offers. British norm: one sincere offer, then assume autonomy. Neither side understood the other's cultural script.

text: Uzbek hears British 'We should do this again sometime' and waits by the phone. Phone never rings. Pragmatic failure: British vague politeness vs Uzbek expectation of concrete follow-through.
analysis: 'We should do this again' in British English is often warm but NON-BINDING. It expresses positive feeling but not commitment. In Uzbek culture, such statements might be taken more literally as actual plans.

text: British colleague says 'That's very brave' about a decision. Uzbek thinks: 'They called me brave! How nice!' Actual meaning: 'That's a risky/possibly stupid decision.'
analysis: British understatement trap. 'Brave' and 'interesting' are often NEGATIVE in British professional context. They're polite ways to express doubt or disagreement without direct confrontation.

text: British response to terrible news: 'Oh dear. That's a bit unfortunate.' American response to same news: 'OH MY GOD THAT'S TERRIBLE!'
analysis: Contrast in emotional expression across English-speaking cultures. British restraint ('a bit unfortunate') can mask strong feelings. Neither is more honest' - they're different cultural codes.
title: Okhshatdim: Melon Comparison
setup:
A: Sizni qovunga o'xshatdim! (I compared you to a melon!)
B: Nega? (Why?)
punchline: A: Ichingiz bo'sh, lekin tashqaringiz chiroyli! (Empty inside, but beautiful outside!)
explanation: This is 'Okhshatdim' - the classic askiya format where performers compare each other to objects. The comparison seems like a compliment (beautiful) but contains gentle criticism (empty). The opponent must now respond with an even cleverer comparison.
pragmaticNote: Unlike Western 'roast' comedy, askiya mockery must be 'subtle, light and kind' - showing wit without humiliation. This demonstrates pragmatic face-work.
uzbekContext: Okhshatdim is one of the oldest payrovs (themes), practiced in Fergana Valley tea houses for centuries.

title: Qofiya: Rhyme Battle
setup:
A: Tog'da qor (Snow on mountain)
B: Ko'lda nor (Camel by lake)
A: Uyda non (Bread in house)
B: Bozorda... (At bazaar...)
punchline: B hesitates: '...odam ko'p!' (many people!) — LOSES! The rhyme pattern (-or, -or, -on) was broken.
explanation: Qofiya requires maintaining rhyme schemes under pressure. Breaking the pattern means losing that round. This tests vocabulary depth and quick thinking.
pragmaticNote: This format shows cooperative competition - the goal is entertainment through linguistic skill, not destruction of the opponent.
uzbekContext: Audiences actively participate by counting and judging. Qofiya battles can last for many rounds.

title: Laqab: The Lamp Nickname
setup:
A: Sizning laqabingiz 'Chiroq' bo'lsin! (Your nickname shall be 'Lamp'!)
B: Nega? (Why?)
punchline: A: Chunki siz qorong'ida ham ko'rinasiz - boshqa hech narsa yo'q bo'lsa ham! (Because you're visible even in darkness - when there's nothing else to see!)
explanation: Laqab involves giving opponents humorous nicknames with elaborate justifications. The 'lamp' seems positive (visible, notable) but implies the person is only noticeable when nothing better is around.
pragmaticNote: The nickname must be clever, not cruel. This is a face-threatening act softened by the performance context and creative framing.
uzbekContext: In Uzbek culture, nicknames (laqab) carry social significance. Askiya nicknames are temporary and playful.

title: Bolasizmi: The Age Trap
setup:
A: Bolasizmi? (Are you a child?)
B: Yo'q, kattaman. (No, I'm an adult.)
punchline: A: Unda nega kattalar kabi gaplashmaysiz? (Then why don't you speak like an adult?)
explanation: Bolasizmi is a yes/no trap. Answering 'yes' admits childishness. Answering 'no' opens you to criticism about adult behavior. There's no safe answer!
pragmaticNote: This teaches that in pragmatics, the literal answer isn't always safe. Questions can be setups, not genuine information requests.
uzbekContext: Master askiyachi prepare responses for BOTH possible answers. The trap is in the question structure itself.

title: Gulmisiz: Flower or Basil?
setup:
A: Gulmisiz, rayhonmisiz? (Are you a flower or basil?)
B: Gulman! (I'm a flower!)
punchline:
A: Afsuski, gullar tez so'liydi... (Unfortunately, flowers wilt quickly...)
[Had B chosen 'basil': 'Rayhon faqat sho'rvaga yaraydi!' (Basil is only good for soup!)]
explanation: This payrov offers a choice, but BOTH options have prepared witty downsides. Beauty (flower) fades quickly. Utility (basil) is mundane. It's a beautiful trap.
pragmaticNote: Loaded questions give an illusion of choice. This is common in many cultures' humor and in everyday pragmatic manipulation.
uzbekContext: Flowers (gul) and herbs like basil (rayhon) have rich symbolic meaning in Uzbek poetry. Askiya plays with these cultural associations.

title: Modern Askiya: Smartphone
setup:
A: Telefoningiz qanday? (How's your phone?)
B: Yangi, zo'r! (New, great!)
punchline: A: Demak, telefoningiz sizdan aqlliroq - u hech bo'lmaganda yangilanadi! (So your phone is smarter than you - at least IT gets updates!)
explanation: Modern askiya applies traditional wit to contemporary topics. The word 'yangilanadi' means both 'updates' (for phones) and 'renews/improves' (for people).
pragmaticNote: This shows askiya is a living tradition that adapts while preserving core structures. Compare to how British humor also updates references.
uzbekContext: Contemporary payrovs include Telefon, Futbol, Mashina (car), Kino (cinema). The tradition evolves with society.
